title: Nidalee and her extreme frustration factor, particularly at the professional level
body: Nidalee is already annoying enough to play against in solo queue. However her worst offenses generally come in professional games. The rate at which she clears the jungle is absolutely offensive. She zones people out of their own jungles and manalessly jumps around, destroying camps at an absurd rate. As a result, the only junglers that are played in the competitive meta are jungles that can scrap with Nidalee. The few tanks that are played are tanks such as Gragas who have game breaking ultimates, absurd innate tankiness, etc. Other than that, I don't see any bruisers aside from Lee Sin, I don't see anybody else besides Elise and Kindred, both of which can fight Nidalee in the early game.

You can't counter jungle someone that clears their whole jungle before you finish your first buff and says Hi to you a level ahead of you with both buffs and already at your other buff ready to kill you.

I hate counter-jungling, but the best way to prevent it is to be the better jungler and have a responsive team. People do double buff camps first then invade, you have to be able to detect and motion. If Nidalee fails, it's an easy 150 gold for top/mid and jg. If your team doesn't care about you (why soloq? matters here) then you'll give up a kill. Unit cohesion is something people have to adapt to, there isn't a champion balance fix to this, unless it's R2Win.

Edit:

Shifting XP away from the buffs and into the other camps, just enough to deny level 3 status from the double-buff camps might stop nidalee's (and other jungles) from doing just those two and invading. That way, another two crows or 1 small golem is needed to reach level three forcing jungles to start another camp taking damage and time.

Balancing around high elo is an absolute necessity because it's the one bracket of play where champion strength starts to seriously matter. In lower elo, differences in player skill are what determines games because the skill differences are massive there. You can win matchups you have absolutely no business winning in bronze and silver because people really don't know what they're doing. At that point, player skill trumps champion strength pretty much always. High elo, where everyone knows how to play, is where raw champion strength really starts to matter. There's a reason Diamond winrates range from 56% at the top all the way to 40% at the bottom while winrates only range from 55% to 44% in League as a whole: champion strength simply matters more the higher elo you go.
